params.text:
• Understanding Emails
  • Attachments
  • Saying Email Addresses

Professional Writing

Understanding Key Email
Vocabulary

Language in Action
Professional Writing: Introduction

Welcome back, everyone! Today, we will study email vocabulary. 

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

1. Understand Emails: We'll learn the different parts of an email and what they mean.

  2. Refer to Attachments: You'll discover how to talk about documents or files you include in your emails.

  3. Say Email Addresses: We'll practice sharing your email address and understanding others'.
Understanding Emails: Key Points

Emails can seem complicated, but they're made up of simple parts! 

Here are some tips to help you understand them:
Look for the From and To:
• This shows who sent the email (From) and who it's going to (To).
Subject Line:
Body:
Attachments:
• This gives a short idea of what the email is about.
• This is the main message of the email.
• Sometimes, emails include extra files like documents or pictures (attachments).
Understanding Emails - Sentences

params.textField:
*Subject*: Meeting Reminder 
Hi *Sarah*, 
I am *writing* to *inform* you about... 
Please let me *know* if you have any *questions*. 
*Thanks*, John

params.text: Attachments: Key Points

Sometimes, emails include extra files or "attachments". These files can be documents, pictures, or other things. 

Here are some helpful phrases to talk about attachments:

• Let the recipient know there's an attachment and what it is.
  • Example: "I've attached the report for your review." (This clearly states there's a report attached)
Mention the attachment in your email:
Use common verbs:
Be specific:
• Simple verbs like "attach," "include," or "send" work well.
• If there are multiple attachments, mention them all or use a phrase like "See the attached files."
Attachments - Sentences

params.textField:
Hi David,
I hope this *email* finds you well.
I *am* writing to send you the sales report for *last* month. You'll find it *attached* to this email.
Please let me know if you have any *questions*.
Thanks,
Sarah

params.text: Choose the BEST way to mention an attachment in an email.
Saying Email Adresses: Key Points

In professional emails, it's important to share your email address clearly or ask for someone else's. 

Here are some tips:

• Don't rely on someone guessing your email address. Spell it out letter by letter.
  • Example: "My email address is bryan@hartford-trading.com”
Spell it out:
Say "at" for "@" symbol:

• When speaking your email address, say "at" instead of the "@" symbol.
  • Example: "My email address is brian at hartford hyphen trading dot com
Saying Email Adresses - Listening
Please listen to the following opinions and fill in the missing words:

Micah:

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You want to see the main message of an email. Where would you look?
Question 2 of 6: An email can have extra files attached. What word can you use to mention these files?
Question 3 of 6: You received an email with a report attached. How can you thank the sender in your reply?
answers:
Thanks for the report attachment! 

Thanks for the email! 

Thanks for your help!

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: The "@" symbol is used in email addresses. How do we say it out loud?
Question 5 of 6: Someone asks for your email address. What's the best way to give it to them?
answers:
My email address is brian.smith at work.com.

It's [email address removed]

You can find me at work.com

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: Micah forgot Sarah's email address. How can Micah ask for it politely?
answers:
What's your email address, Sarah? 

Give me your email! 

I need your email.
